I'm curious about the CHECKCAST issue. Is it well known that the
CHECKCASTs are resistant to compiler optimization?  I didn't realize
that generics presented such a performance concern.

Dan

On Dec 19, 2007 3:11 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
> Colin, I just wanted to second that I believe the GUI stuff is quite
> important for the reasons you stated. They really help you
> understand what's going on and thereby debug and better optimize
> parameters.
>
> Also, SharpNEAT is one of the fastest versions of NEAT available.
> The regression experiments can run 100,000 generations in a few
> hours, which is impressive. Will the same optimizations that allow
> that performance really hold after transferring it over?
>
> ken
>
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <locster01@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Jim,
>
>
> >
> > On 19/12/2007, Jim O'Flaherty, Jr. <jim_oflaherty_jr@...> wrote:
> > >
> > > I am curious as to why you are considering shifting from .NET/C#
> to Java. Given the conversion will cost you development time, what
> advantages are you gaining in Java, or disadvantages in moving away
> from .NET/C#?
> > >
> > > BTW, I ask this as I have been attempting to evaluate performance
> between these two platforms. To what degree, if at all, is your move
> performance motivated?
> >
> >
> > Actually performance isn't really a major factor in my thinking. The
> > Java and .Net compilers and runtime environments are all well
> thought
> > out and fast environments in my opinion. OK so you've got different
> > Java VM's from different vendors for different scenarios, but
> they're
> > all good including the standard (free) ones. And in the .Net world
> you
> > have Mono which was quite slow when I last tried it last (12 months
> > ago ish). But generally if you see significant performance
> differences
> > it's most likely the code you're using, not the environment. As I
> say
> > the generics support in .Net is more performant, so that does tilt
> the
> > performance argument slightly in favour of .Net
> >
> > For me the main argument for Java is the Eclipse IDE. It's far
> easier
> > to navigate through code using views such as the type and call
> > hierarchy, highlighting of variables, errors, warnings, TODO
> comments,
> > etc. on the right hand margin. The CVS/SVN support is really nice to
> > use - Visual Studio's equivalents are either very poor by comparison
> > (SourceSafe) or very expensive (TeamSuite). Ultimately the Java
> coding
> > experience is nicer and makes more efficient use of programmer time
> > IMO - a big plus in my book.
> >
> > So although I prefer the .Net framework, the IDE's let the side
> down.
> > Add to that the fact that Java is more open source friendly and that
> > could sway the argument for me. Yes you can get a free version of
> VS,
> > but (a) it's not as good as Eclipse (also free) and (b) it has some
> > features disabled - 64bit support and multithreaded debugging are
> two
> > I bumped into recently.
> >
> > Development time is an issue. Not so much porting the core algorithm
> > stuff as I'm intending to refactor all of that anyway, but all the
> > graphical stuff and GUI interfaces could be a serious headache.
> >
> > Colin.
> >
>
>
>
>
